terms.definition: Software as a Service - a cloud-based software delivery model where applications are hosted by a service provider and accessed via the internet
A centralized repository of information, documentation, and resources that provides answers to common questions and solutions to problems
A system that tracks and manages changes to documents or code over time, allowing users to revert to previous versions and track revision history
Printed Circuit Board - a board that mechanically supports and electrically connects electronic components using conductive tracks and pads
Visual representations that show the sequence of steps, decisions, and activities in a manufacturing or business process
Standard Operating Procedures - detailed written instructions that describe how to perform routine tasks or processes consistently
Detailed step-by-step documents that provide specific guidance on how to perform particular tasks or operations in a manufacturing environment
A chronological record of all changes, access, and activities related to documents or processes, used for compliance and accountability purposes
The ability for multiple users to simultaneously work on and edit the same document or project with changes visible instantly to all participants
A single, unified platform where all organizational documents, files, and information are stored and managed in one accessible location
The ability to track and document the history, application, or location of materials, processes, or products throughout the manufacturing lifecycle
Systematic processes and procedures designed to ensure that products or services meet specified requirements and standards
Research and Development - the department or activities focused on investigating new technologies, products, or processes for future implementation
The process of ensuring that business operations, processes, and documentation adhere to relevant laws, regulations, and industry standards
A systematic approach to identifying the underlying reasons for problems or defects in processes, rather than just addressing symptoms
